and stock your

grab-and-go-bag.

3

[Insert link here]

Understanding Emergency Events

Evacuation Stages

Evacuation Alert

Be ready to leave on short notice.

Evacuation Order

You are at risk. Leave the area immediately.

Evacuation Rescind

All is currently safe and you can return home.

Flood Advisory Stages

High Streamflow Advisory

River levels are rising or are expected to rise rapidly. Major flooding is not expected. Minor flooding in low-lying areas is possible.

Flood Watch

River levels are rising and will approach or may exceed the river bank. Flooding may occur in areas near affected rivers.

Flood Warning

River levels have exceeded the river bank or will exceed the river bank soon. Flooding may occur in areas near affected rivers.

Links and Resources

[XYZ Regional District/City/FN] resources

[Link 1]

[Link 2]

Flood evacuee guidance

General emergency evacuee guidance information for the public. Always follow the instructions of your Local Authority or First Nation.

River Forecast Centre

Updates on current Flood Advisories in BC.

DriveBC

Latest travel and highway updates in BC. Find your regional DriveBC X (Twitter) account.

PreparedBC

Learn how to prepare for floods with resources from PreparedBC.

item.title: Earthquake
item.dc:creator: mhaswell
item.content:encoded:
Current Situation

Earthquake Summary

Local Time

15:07:30 PDT

Magnitude

3.4

Latitude

53.65 North

UT Date & Time

  • 2022/09/21
  • 22:07:30 UT

Depth

5.00 km

Longitude

122.94 West

Find more details from Natural Resources Canada

Recommended Actions

1

Remain calm

Stay calm and move carefully. Check for unstable objects and other hazards above and around you.

2

Check for damage and hazards

  • Put on protective shoes and clothing before checking for damage and hazards
  • If you smell gas or rotten eggs, leave the building immediately. Call 9-1-1 or your gas company's emergency phone number

3

Listen to instructions

  • Follow local information on the web, social media, radio and TV
  • If further actions are required in your community, local officials will provide instruction

4

Report the earthquake

  • DO NOT call 9-1-1 to report the earthquake
  • If you felt the earthquake, report it at Earthquakes Canada

5

Aftershocks could occur:

  • When you feel shaking, drop, cover and hold on
  • Wait for the shaking to stop and count to 60 before getting up

Links and Resources

Natural Resources Canada

Earthquakes Canada provides information on earthquakes that occur in Canada including magnitude, location, time and felt reports.

U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)

USGS provides international information on earthquakes.

National Tsunami Warning Center (NTWC)

NTWC provides international information and alerts on earthquakes and potential tsunamis.

Preparing for Earthquakes

Earthquakes can't be predicted. Take the following steps to stay safe:

Drop, cover and hold on

  • Drop to your hands and knees. If you're inside, stay inside â€“ don't run outdoors or to other rooms
  • Cover your head and neck with your arm and take shelter under a sturdy piece of furniture
  • Hold on to your shelter, covering your head and neck until the shaking stops. Then count to 60 before getting up.

Prepare your home

Before an earthquake, you can help prevent injuries and damage by making some changes inside your home.

Build an emergency kit and grab-and-go bags

After an earthquake you may need to shelter at home with an emergency kit or you may need to leave quickly with a grab-and-go bag.

Research insurance options

Home insurance policies in B.C. cover earthquake damage and losses. Call your insurance representative to discuss your coverage or contact the Insurance Bureau of Canada at 1-844-227-5422.

item.title: Amber Alert
item.dc:creator: mhaswell
item.content:encoded:
Current Situation

Call 9-1-1 to report sightings. Do not approach.

Victim name: Phaivanh Correia-Chanthabouala

Enlarge

Enlarge

Age: 3

Gender: Male

Height: 2 ft 0 inch

Weight: 30 lbs

Hair Colour: Black

Eye Colour: Brown

Race: Asian

Description

3-years old, 2ft, black hair, wearing grey zip up, blue pants and red shoes.

Suspect name: Jenny Chanthabouala

Enlarge

Age: 30

Gender: Female

Height: 5 ft 2 inch

Weight: 106 lbs

Hair Colour: Black

Eye Colour: Brown

Race: Asian

Description:

Asian female, tattoo sleeve right arm, long black dreadlock hair, black jacket, black toque, glasses, grey sweatpants, red/yellow/turquoise striped messenger bag, brown Ugg boots.

Vehicle: Name

Enlarge

Year: 2008

Colour: Dark Grey

Make: Dodge

Model: Journey

License number: 000000

Province: B.C.

Type: ___

Style: ___

Vehicle is: Stolen

Description:

Vehicle is a black Dodge Journey with tinted windows and a dent on the driver's side door. It has a license plate number of ABC123 and was last seen heading eastbound on Main Street.

Recommended Actions

1

Be aware

Watch for the child, suspect, and/or vehicle described in the alert.

2

DO NOT approach the victim or suspect

  • Do not attempt to catch the child or suspect yourself
  • Do not attempt to stop the vehicle

3

Report any sightings

  • Immediately report any sightings to the police by calling 9-1-1
  • Provide the location and a description of the victim, suspect, and/or vehicle

Visit the B.C. RCMP Amber Alert Program website to learn more.

Links and Resources

B.C. RCMP Newsroom

For updates, follow @BCRMP on Twitter or visit the BC RCMP News Room.

BC Emergency Alert

This Amber Alert was broadcast on radio, TV, and to connect mobile devices.

item.title: Emergency Alert
item.dc:creator: mhaswell
item.content:encoded:
BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

item.title: Heat
item.dc:creator: mhaswell
item.content:encoded:
Current Situation

Active Heat Warnings in B.C.

Northeast

  • Northern Interior
  • Central Interior, including Chilcotin, Cariboos
  • Prince George
  • North Thompson
  • North Columbia
  • BC Peace, Bulkley Valley
  • The Lakes
  • Fort Nelson

Northwest

  • Central and Northern Coast (inland and coastal regions)
  • Northern Vancouver Island
  • Northwestern B.C.

Southeast

  • Central and Northern Coast (inland and coastal regions)
  • Northern Vancouver Island
  • Northwestern B.C.

Southwest

  • Western Metro Vancouver including the North Shore
  • City of Vancouver and Richmond
  • Howe Sound
  • Whistler
  • Sunshine Coast
  • Vancouver Island (except northern sections)

Southwest inland

  • Eastern Metro Vancouver including Coquitlam and Surrey
  • Fraser Valley

Heat Warning Map

Cooling Centres

Cooling centres

In response to Heat Warnings, cooling centres may be opened for the public at the discretion of local governments and First Nations in affected areas.

Visit your First Nation or local government website for cooling centres in your area.

Contact a healthcare provider or call HealthLinkBC at 8-1-1 if you think you are experiencing heat-related symptoms. Mild to moderate heat illness can quickly become severe. Call 9-1-1 in case of medical emergency.

Heat is more dangerous to young children and the elderly. If you are safe and able to, check on your neighbours and elders and look for signs of heat-related illness.

British Columbia - Vancouver Island

Cowichan Tribes

Nanaimo Woodgrove Center

YMCA Duncan

British Columbia - Southwest

Richmond Community Hall

Whistler Village Stadium

Sunshine Coast Legion

Heat Safety and Preparedness

Preparing for heat

BC Centre for Disease Control

PreparedBC

Extreme Heat Guide (PDF, 9.4 MB)

Health Authorities - Heat response information

Fraser Health

Interior Health

First Nations Health Authority

Island Health

Northern Health

Vancouver Coastal Health

Understanding Heat Warnings

Heat Warning

Daytime and overnight temperatures are higher than usual, but they are not getting hotter every day. Take the usual steps to stay cool.

Extreme Heat Emergency

Daytime and overnight temperatures are higher than usual and are getting hotter every day. Activate your emergency plan for heat.

Flood Watches and Warnings

The public is advised to stay clear of the fast-flowing rivers and potentially unstable riverbanks during the high-streamflow period.

Flood Warning - South Coast & Vancouver Island (PDF)

jglkfdgj;dlkfgjd;lkgfjds;lfkgjds;lf

Flood Watch - Englishman River and South Vancouver Island (PDF)

fdjdkfjghkfdljhgldkjfghldsf

Flood Watch - Chilcotin Region (PDF)

djfhdlkfjghdlkfjghldskfg

Visit the River Forecast Centre

dflkjs;lfkjsd;lfkasjdf;lakds

Recommended Actions

1

Stay clear from hazards

Stay clear of rivers. Riverbanks may be unstable and dangerous.

2

Understand Evacuation stages

Make sure you know what to do if your area is issued an Evacuation Order, Alert, or Rescind. See definitions below.

3

Stay informed, stay safe

Refer to your local government for information specific to your community.

Links and Resources

Flood evacuee guidance

Emergency evacuee guidance information for the public. Always follow the instructions of your Local Authority or First Nation.

What happens during a flood

Get information about flood advisories and warnings, evacuation stages, building a sandbag dike and coping with stress.

PreparedBC

Learn how to prepare for floods with resources from PreparedBC.

item.title: Tsunami
item.dc:creator: mhaswell
item.content:encoded:
Current Situation

This tsunami is linked to a current earthquake

Tsunami Notification Zones

Earthquake Summary

Local Time

15:07:30 PDT

Magnitude

3.4

Latitude

53.65 North

UT Date & Time

  • 2022/09/21
  • 22:07:30 UT

Depth

5.00 km

Longitude

122.94 West

Areas of Impact

Zone A: North Coast and Haida Gwaii

Detailed map of Zone A (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Zone B: Central Coast and Northeast Vancouver Island coast including Kitimat, Bella Coola, and Port Hardy

Detailed map of Zone B (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Zone C: West coast of Vancouver Island from Cape Scott to Port Renfrew

Detailed map of Zone C (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Zone D: Juan de Fuca Strait from Jordan River to Greater Victoria (including the Saanich Peninsula)

Detailed map of Zone D (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Zone E: Strait of Georgia (including the Gulf Islands), Greater Vancouver and Johnstone Strait

Detailed map of Zone E (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Recommended Actions

People in coastal areas that are at risk are advised to stay away from the shoreline and heed instructions from local authorities. If you are in a tsunami [advisory/watch/warning] area:

1

Leave the water now

Move out of the ocean, off the beach, and away from harbours, marinas, breakwaters, bays and inlets

2

Don't go to the ocean

Do not go to the ocean to observe the tsunami

3

Follow official instructions

Be alert to and follow instructions from your local emergency officials because they may have more detailed or specific information for your location

4

Move your boat

Boat operators: where time and conditions permit, move your boat out to sea to a depth of at least 180 feet; if at sea avoid entering shallow water, harbours, marinas, bays, and inlets to avoid floating and submerged debris and strong currents

5

Wait for the 'All Clear'

Do not return to the coast until local emergency officials indicate it is safe to do so

6

Do NOT call 9-1-1 to report the earthquake

It is important to leave these lines open for those in urgent need. Only call 9-1-1 when a life is at stake

Links and Resources

Environment Canada Alerts

Use this site to view Tsunami Notification Zones on an interactive map.

National Tsunami Warning Center (NTWC)

NTWC provides international information and alerts on earthquakes and potential tsunamis.

Natural Resources Canada

Earthquakes Canada provides information on earthquakes that occur in Canada including magnitude, location, time and felt reports.

U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)

USGS provides international information on earthquakes.

Tsunami Threat Levels

Warning

Flood wave possible. Full evacuation suggested.

Advisory

Strong currents likely. Stay away from the shore.

Watch

Danger level not yet known. Stay alert for more information

Information Statement

Minor waves at most. No action suggested.

Cancellation

Tidal gauges show no wave activity. Confirm safety for local areas.

Know Your Tsunami Notification Zones

Zone A

North coast and Haida Gwaii

Zone B

Central coast and northeast Vancouver Island coast including Kitimat, Bella Coola, and Port Hardy

Zone C

West coast of Vancouver Island from Cape Scott to Port Renfrew

Zone D

Juan de Fuca Strait from Jordan River to Greater Victoria (including the Saanich Peninsula)

Zone E

Strait of Georgia (including the Gulf Islands)
Greater Vancouver and Johnstone Strait

item.title: Earthquake - Catastrophic
item.dc:creator: mhaswell
item.content:encoded:
Current Situation

This earthquake is linked to a current tsunami

BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

Earthquake Summary

Local Time

15:07:30 PDT

Magnitude

3.4

Latitude

53.65 North

UT Date & Time

  • 2022/09/21
  • 22:07:30 UT

Depth

5.00 km

Longitude

122.94 West

Find more details from Natural Resources Canada

Recommended Actions

1

Remain calm

Stay calm and move carefully, checking for unstable objects and other hazards above and around you.

2

Check for damage and hazards

  • Put on protective shoes and clothing before checking for damage and hazards
  • If you smell gas or rotten eggs, leave the building immediately. Call 9-1-1 or your gas company's emergency phone number

3

Listen to instructions

  • Follow local information on the web, social media, radio and TV
  • If further actions are required in your community, local officials will provide instruction

4

Report the earthquake

  • DO NOT call 9-1-1 to report the earthquake
  • If you felt the earthquake, report it at Earthquakes Canada

5

Aftershocks could occur:

  • When you feel shaking, drop, cover and hold on
  • Wait for the shaking to stop and count to 60 before getting up

Links and Resources

Natural Resources Canada

Earthquakes Canada provides information on earthquakes that occur in Canada including magnitude, location, time and felt reports.

U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)

USGS provides international information on earthquakes.

National Tsunami Warning Center (NTWC)

NTWC provides international information and alerts on earthquakes and potential tsunamis.

Preparing for Earthquakes

Earthquakes can't be predicted. Take the following steps to stay safe:

Drop, cover and hold on

  • Drop to your hands and knees. If you're inside, stay inside â€“ don't run outdoors or to other rooms
  • Cover your head and neck with your arm and take shelter under a sturdy piece of furniture
  • Hold on to your shelter, covering your head and neck until the shaking stops. Then count to 60 before getting up.

Prepare your home

Before an earthquake, you can help prevent injuries and damage by making some changes inside your home.

Build an emergency kit and grab-and-go bags

After an earthquake you may need to shelter at home with an emergency kit or you may need to leave quickly with a grab-and-go bag.

Research insurance options

Home insurance policies in B.C. cover earthquake damage and losses. Call your insurance representative to discuss your coverage or contact the Insurance Bureau of Canada at 1-844-227-5422.

Travel Information

Drop, cover and hold on

  • Drop to your hands and knees. If you're inside, stay inside â€“ don't run outdoors or to other rooms
  • Cover your head and neck with your arm and take shelter under a sturdy piece of furniture
  • Hold on to your shelter, covering your head and neck until the shaking stops. Then count to 60 before getting up.

Prepare your home

Before an earthquake, you can help prevent injuries and damage by making some changes inside your home.

Build an emergency kit and grab-and-go bags

After an earthquake you may need to shelter at home with an emergency kit or you may need to leave quickly with a grab-and-go bag.

Research insurance options

Home insurance policies in B.C. cover earthquake damage and losses. Call your insurance representative to discuss your coverage or contact the Insurance Bureau of Canada at 1-844-227-5422.

Essential Assistance

  • Drop to your hands and knees. If you're inside, stay inside â€“ don't run outdoors or to other rooms
  • Cover your head and neck with your arm and take shelter under a sturdy piece of furniture
  • Hold on to your shelter, covering your head and neck until the shaking stops. Then count to 60 before getting up.

Prepare your home

Before an earthquake, you can help prevent injuries and damage by making some changes inside your home.

Build an emergency kit and grab-and-go bags

After an earthquake you may need to shelter at home with an emergency kit or you may need to leave quickly with a grab-and-go bag.

Research insurance options

Home insurance policies in B.C. cover earthquake damage and losses. Call your insurance representative to discuss your coverage or contact the Insurance Bureau of Canada at 1-844-227-5422.

item.title: Tsunami - Catastrophic
item.dc:creator: mhaswell
item.content:encoded:
Current Situation

This tsunami is linked to a current earthquake

BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

BC Emergency Alert Message

Issued: May 10, 2023 at 2:00 pm

Evacuation Order issued by the Peace River Regional District, with support from EMBC. Immediately evacuate if you are in the evacuation area or directed to do so. The Bearhole Lake Wildfire is creating significant risk to life safety. Evacuate via Hwy 671 to Range Rd 131, North to Hwy 43 OR Hwy 52 East, North to BC Hwy 2. If you are trapped and unable to evacuate call 911 and report your location ASAP. For more information go to the PRRD website or social media. Evacuation area â€“ The community of Kelly Lake, 5km North of Kelly Lake, 5km South of Kelly Lake, 4km West of the Alberta border.

Tsunami Notification Zones

Earthquake Summary

Local Time

15:07:30 PDT

Magnitude

3.4

Latitude

53.65 North

UT Date & Time

  • 2022/09/21
  • 22:07:30 UT

Depth

5.00 km

Longitude

122.94 West

Areas of Impact

Zone A: North Coast and Haida Gwaii

Detailed map of Zone A (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Zone B: Central Coast and Northeast Vancouver Island coast including Kitimat, Bella Coola, and Port Hardy

Detailed map of Zone B (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Zone C: West coast of Vancouver Island from Cape Scott to Port Renfrew

Detailed map of Zone C (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Zone D: Juan de Fuca Strait from Jordan River to Greater Victoria (including the Saanich Peninsula)

Detailed map of Zone D (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Zone E: Strait of Georgia (including the Gulf Islands), Greater Vancouver and Johnstone Strait

Detailed map of Zone E (PDF)

Expected Wave Times

Prince Rupert: 11:02am

Haida Gwaii: 11:03am

Recommended Actions

People in coastal areas that are at risk are advised to stay away from the shoreline and heed instructions from local authorities. If you are in a tsunami [advisory/watch/warning] area:

1

Leave the water now

Move out of the ocean, off the beach, and away from harbours, marinas, breakwaters, bays and inlets

2

Don't go to the ocean

Do not go to the ocean to observe the tsunami

3

Follow official instructions

Be alert to and follow instructions from your local emergency officials because they may have more detailed or specific information for your location

4

Move your boat

Boat operators: where time and conditions permit, move your boat out to sea to a depth of at least 180 feet; if at sea avoid entering shallow water, harbours, marinas, bays, and inlets to avoid floating and submerged debris and strong currents

5

Wait for the 'All Clear'

Do not return to the coast until local emergency officials indicate it is safe to do so

6

Do NOT call 9-1-1 to report the earthquake

It is important to leave these lines open for those in urgent need. Only call 9-1-1 when a life is at stake

Links and Resources

Environment Canada Alerts

Use this site to view Tsunami Notification Zones on an interactive map.

National Tsunami Warning Center (NTWC)

NTWC provides international information and alerts on earthquakes and potential tsunamis.

Natural Resources Canada

Earthquakes Canada provides information on earthquakes that occur in Canada including magnitude, location, time and felt reports.

U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)

USGS provides international information on earthquakes.

Tsunami Threat Levels

Warning

Flood wave possible. Full evacuation suggested.

Advisory

Strong currents likely. Stay away from the shore.

Watch

Danger level not yet known. Stay alert for more information

Information Statement

Minor waves at most. No action suggested.

Cancellation

Tidal gauges show no wave activity. Confirm safety for local areas.

Know Your Tsunami Notification Zones

Zone A

North coast and Haida Gwaii

Zone B

Central coast and northeast Vancouver Island coast including Kitimat, Bella Coola, and Port Hardy

Zone C

West coast of Vancouver Island from Cape Scott to Port Renfrew

Zone D

Juan de Fuca Strait from Jordan River to Greater Victoria (including the Saanich Peninsula)

Zone E

Strait of Georgia (including the Gulf Islands)
Greater Vancouver and Johnstone Strait

Travel Information

Earthquakes can't be predicted. Take the following steps to stay safe:

Drop, cover and hold on

  • Drop to your hands and knees. If you're inside, stay inside â€“ don't run outdoors or to other rooms
  • Cover your head and neck with your arm and take shelter under a sturdy piece of furniture
  • Hold on to your shelter, covering your head and neck until the shaking stops. Then count to 60 before getting up.

Prepare your home

Before an earthquake, you can help prevent injuries and damage by making some changes inside your home.

Build an emergency kit and grab-and-go bags

After an earthquake you may need to shelter at home with an emergency kit or you may need to leave quickly with a grab-and-go bag.

Research insurance options

Home insurance policies in B.C. cover earthquake damage and losses. Call your insurance representative to discuss your coverage or contact the Insurance Bureau of Canada at 1-844-227-5422.

Essential Assistance

Drop, cover and hold on

  • Drop to your hands and knees. If you're inside, stay inside â€“ don't run outdoors or to other rooms
  • Cover your head and neck with your arm and take shelter under a sturdy piece of furniture
  • Hold on to your shelter, covering your head and neck until the shaking stops. Then count to 60 before getting up.

Prepare your home

Before an earthquake, you can help prevent injuries and damage by making some changes inside your home.

Build an emergency kit and grab-and-go bags

After an earthquake you may need to shelter at home with an emergency kit or you may need to leave quickly with a grab-and-go bag.

Research insurance options

Home insurance policies in B.C. cover earthquake damage and losses. Call your insurance representative to discuss your coverage or contact the Insurance Bureau of Canada at 1-844-227-5422.
